title: What's the technology behind Google Maps? - Quora

response.answer_text: Google Map gives accurate information about the routes and views of the whole world through his Street View car! Street View is a technology featured in Google Maps and Google Earth that provides interactive panoramas along many streets of the world. It was launched in several cities in the United States in 2007, and has since expanded to include cities and rural areas around the world. Streets with available Street View imagery are shown as blue lines on Google Maps. Streets with available Street View imagery are shown as blue lines on Google Maps. Google Street View displays panoramas of stitched images. Most photography is done by car, but some is done on a three-wheeler, boat, snowmobile, and underwater equipment as well as on foot. Some pictures of Google Street View car.    [1]      Spreading LOVE🇮🇳 Ashar Jami (عشار جامى) (अशर जामी)✍️ JK. Footnotes[1] Ashar Jami) (عشر جامع (अशर जामी)

There are what we call the Global Navigation Satellite Systems (GNSS). These are the various satelites systems  whose work is to perform global geo-spatial positioning. These systems include the following; GPS/A-GPS by the US Govt.GLONASS by the Russian Govt.BDS by the Chinese Govt.Galileo by the European UnionAll those system do the same thing - mark positions on the globe though they might differ in accuracy, coverage and availability. Google Maps is a web and mobile application based maping service by Google. Technology: On the web, especially on devices with no GNSS, such as desktop computers, Google Maps offers an interactive map that be searched and scrolled to find places, measure distances, plan routes, etc. On mobile devices (with GNSS), Google Maps works with the devices' inbuilt GNSS to determine location, measure distances, give corner-by-corner directions, etc. Google Maps can work without a GNSS (like on the web to find places and measure distances) but it has more functions if used on a device with a Global Navigation Satellite System. Such extended functions include precise location and directions.
